6. Maxwell's Equations and Boundary Conditions
6.1 Dynamic equations
\[
\left\{\begin{array}{cl}
\nabla \cdot \vec{E}=\frac{\rho_{t}}{\varepsilon_{o}} \\
\nabla \times \vec{E}=-\frac{\partial \vec{B}}{\partial t} \\
\nabla \cdot \vec{B}=0 & \text { Gauss's Law } \\
\nabla \times \vec{B}=\mu_{o} \vec{J}_{t}
\end{array}\right\} \quad \text { Faraday's Law } \quad \text { Ao magnetic charge }
\]

The dynamic equations are essentially the same as the static equations, except with the introduction of Faraday's Law. However, these four equations are not consistent. James Clerk Maxwell modified the equations and recognized them as the Maxwell's Equations.
6.2 The inconsistence

Take the divergence on both sides of the Faraday's equation:
\[
\begin{array}{l}
\nabla \times \vec{E}=-\frac{\partial \vec{B}}{\partial t} \\
\nabla \cdot \nabla \times \vec{E}=-\nabla \cdot \frac{\partial \vec{B}}{\partial t}=-\frac{\partial}{\partial t}(\nabla \cdot \vec{B})
\end{array}
\]

The left-hand side of the last equation is zero because divergence of a curl is always zero. The right-hand side of the equation is also equal to zero because \( \nabla \cdot \vec{B}=0 \) is one of the dynamic equations. This is perfectly consistence. However, the Ampere's Equation does not seem to work out as well.
\[
\begin{array}{l}
\nabla \times \vec{B}=\mu_{o} \vec{J}_{t} \\
\nabla \cdot \nabla \times \vec{B}=\mu_{o}\left(\nabla \cdot \vec{J}_{t}\right)
\end{array}
\]

On the left-hand side, a divergence of a curl is zero. But why is \( \nabla \cdot \vec{J}_{t}=0 \) on the right?
6.3 Continuity Equation

In calculus, if \( \rho \) is a function of position and time, and the position \( x(t) \) is a dependent variable, then the total derivative of \( \rho \) is written as:
\[
\frac{d}{d t} \rho(x(t), t)=\frac{d \rho}{d t}=\frac{\partial \rho}{\partial t}+\frac{\partial \rho}{\partial x} \cdot \frac{d x}{d t}=\frac{\partial \rho}{\partial t}+\frac{\partial \rho}{\partial x} \cdot v=\frac{\partial \rho}{\partial t}+\frac{\partial}{\partial x} \cdot(\rho v)
\]
Maxwell Equations

The velocity v in Eqn. (6.5) is assumed to be location independent. In 3-dimensions, the velocity is expressed in vector form, and so is its derivative. The total derivative of \( \rho \) now reads:
\[
\frac{d}{d t} \rho(\vec{r}(t), t)=\frac{\partial \rho}{\partial t}+\nabla \cdot(\rho \vec{v}) \equiv \frac{\partial \rho}{\partial t}+\nabla \cdot \vec{J}
\]
where \( \vec{J} \equiv \rho \vec{v} \) is the flux of \( \rho \). In fluid dynamics, \( \rho \) is the mass density, so J is the mass flux (the amount of mass pass through per unit cross-sectional area per unit time). In thermodynamics, if \( \rho \) is the heat energy density, then \( J \) is the energy flux. In electrodynamics, \( \rho \) is the charge density, and \( J \) is the electrical charge flux (or simply the current density).

In most physical systems, there are conservation laws: conservation of masses, conservation of charges...etc. This translates into a zero total derivative \( \mathrm{d} \rho / \mathrm{dt}=0 \).
\[
0=\frac{\partial \rho}{\partial t}+\nabla \cdot \vec{J}
\]

This is referred to as the Continuity Equation. In electrodynamics, it simply says if the charges are moving out of a volume (in form of a current), the charge density inside the volume must be decreasing. It is just another way to write the conservation of charges.
6.4 Maxwell's contribution

Starting with Gauss's Law:
\[
\begin{array}{l}
\nabla \cdot \vec{E}=\frac{\rho_{t}}{\varepsilon_{o}} \\
\frac{\partial \rho_{t}}{\partial t}=\frac{\partial}{\partial t}\left(\varepsilon_{o} \nabla \cdot \vec{E}\right)=\nabla \cdot\left(\varepsilon_{o} \frac{\partial \vec{E}}{\partial t}\right)
\end{array}
\]

And insert this into the continuity equation:
\[
0=\frac{\partial \rho}{\partial t}+\nabla \cdot \vec{J}_{t}=\nabla \cdot\left(\vec{J}_{t}+\varepsilon_{o} \frac{\partial \vec{E}}{\partial t}\right)
\]

So \( \nabla \cdot \vec{J}_{t} \neq 0 \), but the divergence of the modified current density in Eqn.(6.8) is.
Faraday added \( -\frac{\partial \vec{B}}{\partial t} \) to the \( \nabla \times \vec{E} \) equation to take care of the time-varying magnetic field. Likewise, Maxwell modified the Ampere's Law equation with a similar term:
\[
\begin{array}{l}
\nabla \times \vec{B}=\mu_{o} \vec{J}_{t} \\
\Rightarrow \nabla \times \vec{B}=\mu_{o}\left(\vec{J}_{t}+\varepsilon_{o} \frac{\partial \vec{E}}{\partial t}\right)
\end{array}
\]
Maxwell Equations

Now, take the divergence on this modified Ampere's Law equation:
\[
\nabla \cdot \nabla \times \vec{B}=\mu_{o} \nabla \cdot\left(\vec{J}_{t}+\varepsilon_{o} \frac{\partial \vec{E}}{\partial t}\right)=0
\]

The left-hand side is a divergence of a curl which is equal to zero. The right-hand side is also zero from the continuity equation.

With this modification, the 4 equations (grouped as the Maxwell's Equations) are consistent and read as:
\[
\left\{\begin{array}{c}
\nabla \cdot \vec{E}=\frac{\rho_{t}}{\varepsilon_{o}} \\
\nabla \times \vec{E}=-\frac{\partial \vec{B}}{\partial t} \\
\nabla \cdot \vec{B}=0 \\
\nabla \times \vec{B}=\mu_{o}\left(\vec{J}_{t}+\varepsilon_{o} \frac{\partial \vec{E}}{\partial t}\right)
\end{array}\right\}
\]

Gauss's Law

Faraday's Law

Together with the Lorentz Force equation, which is just combining the electric and the magnetic forces: \( \vec{F}=q(\vec{E}+\vec{v} \times \vec{B}) \), the Maxwell's equations describe all the phenomena in classical electrodynamics, including optics.
6.5 B and H fields

Calculating electromagnetic field in matter can be complicated due to the extra contribution from the molecules in terms of polarization and magnetization. To simplify the task, electric displacement vector D was introduced to only keep track of the free charges, and magnetic field intensity H to account for the free current.
Straightly speaking, B field is called the magnetic induction, or magnetic flux density, while H field is referred to as the magnetic field intensity. Most people, including this book, loosely called them by the same name as "magnetic field".
In electricity, a relative dielectric constant was used to approximation the effect of the polarization induced in the material. In magnetism, permeability is the parameter to describe the magnetic behavior of the material. Away from the atomic scale, these are good approximations to visualize the mean field behavior in the macroscopic world.
\( \vec{B}=\mu \vec{H}=\mu_{o} \mu_{r} \vec{H} \)
\( \mu_{\mathrm{r}} \) is the relative permeability, equals to one for non-magnetic materials.
Like \( \varepsilon \) in dielectric, \( \mu \) is a tensor (or matrix) to be more exact. What that means is the H field and B field do not have to be in the same direction, especially viewing in microscopic scales.

6.6 Maxwell's Equation of free charges and free current

In terms of free charges and free current, Maxwell's equations can be rewritten as:
\[
\left\{\begin{array}{c}
\nabla \cdot \vec{D}=\rho_{f} \\
\nabla \times \vec{E}=-\frac{\partial \vec{B}}{\partial t} \\
\nabla \cdot \vec{B}=0 \\
\nabla \times \vec{H}=\vec{J}_{f}+\frac{\partial \vec{D}}{\partial t}
\end{array}\right\} \Leftrightarrow\left\{\begin{array}{c}
\oint \vec{D} \cdot d \vec{a}=Q_{f} \\
\oint \vec{E} \cdot d \vec{\ell}=-\frac{\partial}{\partial t} \int \vec{B} \cdot d \vec{a} \\
\oint \vec{B} \cdot d \vec{a}=0 \\
\oint \vec{H} \cdot d \vec{\ell}=I_{f}+\frac{\partial}{\partial t} \int \vec{D} \cdot d \vec{a}
\end{array}\right\}
\]

Free charges refer to the net charges that are deposited or induced in the material, as opposed to the bound charges or polarization charges due to the polarization of the molecules. Free current is the real current imposed onto a conductor, not counting the equivalent current due to the change of polarization or magnetization.
6.7 E and \( \mathrm{D}, \mathrm{B} \) and H fields

How to determine whether E or D should be used? And B or H field?
- H relates to free current, which can be measured using an ammeter.
- B highly depends on the material and its history (hysteresis).
- H is easily measurable (via free current) when we build an electromagnet.
- D is related to free charges.
- E is related to the voltage \( V=-\int \vec{E} \cdot \overrightarrow{d \ell} \), which can be measured with a voltmeter.

Since E and H fields tie to measurements more closely, they are being used more often. But all 4 field descriptions are being used in different disciplines and industries.
6.8 Phasor equations

The Maxwell's Equations in terms of E and H are written as:
\[
\left\{\begin{array}{c}
\varepsilon \nabla \cdot \vec{E}=\rho_{f} \\
\nabla \times \vec{E}=-\mu \frac{\partial \vec{H}}{\partial t} \\
\nabla \cdot \vec{H}=0 \\
\nabla \times \vec{H}=\vec{J}_{f}+\varepsilon \frac{\partial \vec{E}}{\partial t}
\end{array}\right\}
\]

This will be the starting point of the later chapters in electromagnetic waves.

Time-varying electromagnetic fields are functions of space and time. Without getting into the details of separation of variables, one can imagine writing the field equations in Fourier components. In other words, any periodic time function can be written as a sum of harmonic sequence. We can certainly choose to look at one frequency component at a time.
\[
\begin{array}{l}
\vec{E}(\vec{r}, t)=\vec{E}_{o}(\vec{r}) e^{j \omega t} \\
\vec{B}(\vec{r}, t)=\vec{B}_{o}(\vec{r}) e^{j \omega t}
\end{array}
\]

The spatial vectors without the time piece are called the phasor of the functions. Put these in the Maxwell's Equations (6.16), one can pull out a factor of \( j \omega \) from the time derivative. And the result is referred to as the phasor equations.
\[
\left\{\begin{array}{c}
\varepsilon \nabla \cdot \vec{E}=\rho_{f} \\
\nabla \times \vec{E}=-\mu \frac{\partial \vec{H}}{\partial t} \\
\nabla \cdot \vec{H}=0 \\
\nabla \times \vec{H}=\vec{J}_{f}+\varepsilon \frac{\partial \vec{E}}{\partial t}
\end{array}\right\} \Leftrightarrow\left\{\begin{array}{c}
\nabla \cdot \vec{E}=\frac{\rho_{f}}{\varepsilon} \\
\nabla \times \vec{E}=-j \omega \mu \vec{H} \\
\nabla \cdot \vec{H}=0 \\
\nabla \times \vec{H}=\vec{J}_{f}+j \omega \varepsilon \vec{E}
\end{array}\right\}
\]

The Maxwell's Equations relate electric field with the magnetic field. The phasor equations make the coupling between E and H fields through simple algebraic manipulations.

Example (6.1) - \( \vec{H}(\vec{r}, t)=\hat{x} 0.01 \cos \left(9 \cdot 10^{9} t+30 z\right) \mathrm{A} / \mathrm{m} \) in vacuum with no electrical current. Find E.

In general, the number in front of \( t \) is the angular frequency \( \omega \), and in front of the spatial parameter is the wave number in that direction. (More details in the plane wave chapter.)
\[
\begin{array}{l}
\nabla \times \vec{H}=j \omega \varepsilon \vec{E} \\
\nabla \times \vec{H}=\left|\begin{array}{ccc}
\hat{x} & \hat{y} & \hat{z} \\
\frac{\partial}{\partial x} & \frac{\partial}{\partial y} & \frac{\partial}{\partial z} \\
0.01 \cos (\omega t+30 z) & 0 & 0
\end{array}\right|=-\hat{y} 0.01(30) \sin (\omega t+30 z) \\
j \omega \varepsilon \vec{E}=-\hat{y} 0.3 \sin (\omega t+30 z) \\
\vec{E}=\frac{-\hat{y} 0.3 \sin (\omega t+30 z)}{j \omega \varepsilon_{o}}=j \frac{\hat{y} 0.3 \sin (\omega t+30 z)}{\left(9 \cdot 10^{9}\right)\left(10^{-9} / 36 \pi\right)}=j \hat{y}(1.2 \pi) \sin (\omega t+30 z)
\end{array}
\]

The imaginary number j also means 90 degrees ahead in phase. So, \( \mathrm{j} \sin (\theta) \sim \sin \left(\theta+90^{\circ}\right) \) \( =\cos (\theta) \), and \( \vec{E}=\hat{y}(3.77) \cos \left(9 \cdot 10^{9} t+30 z\right) \mathrm{V} / \mathrm{m} \).

6.9 Boundary conditions

It was shown in electrostatics that electric field is affected by the presence of a conductor. Specifically, electric field is bent toward the conductor, so it is always perpendicular to the surface of a conductor. In other materials, the field will bend somewhat when it is passing through, much the same way the light refracts through dielectrics. Let's examine the field behaviors at the boundary.
6.9.1 Normal component of \( D \) field

For media 1 and 2 as shown, imagine a very thin pill box cutting through the boundary. The normal components of the D fields are related using Gauss's Law:
\[
\begin{array}{l}
\oint \vec{D} \cdot d \vec{a}=Q_{f} \\
D_{1 n} A-D_{2 n} A=\sigma_{s} A \\
D_{1 n}-D_{2 n}=\sigma_{s}
\end{array}
\]
\( \sigma_{\mathrm{s}} \) is the surface charge density.
The pill box is so infinitesimally thin that there will be no volume charge enclosed. If both media are non-conducting dielectric, \( \mathrm{D}_{1 \mathrm{n}}=\mathrm{D}_{2 \mathrm{n}} \). If medium 2 is a conductor, for example, then \( \mathrm{D}_{2} \) would be zero because there is no electric field (or D field) inside a good conductor. But there is a surface charge because free charges always stay on the surface of a good conductor (Section 2.8.2), therefore, \( \mathrm{D}_{1 \mathrm{n}}=\sigma_{\mathrm{s}} \). E and D fields are related by \( \varepsilon \), so one can write the relationship for the normal component of electric fields as well:
\[
\varepsilon_{o}\left(\varepsilon_{r 1} E_{1 n}-\varepsilon_{r 2} E_{2 n}\right)=\sigma_{s}
\]
6.9.2 Tangential component of E field

To look at the tangential components of the fields, we draw a thin contour just above and below the surface of the boundary.
\[
\begin{array}{l}
\oint \vec{E} \cdot \overrightarrow{d \ell}=-\frac{\partial}{\partial t} \int \vec{B} \cdot \not \subset a=0 \\
E_{1 t} \ell-E_{2 t} \ell=0 \\
E_{1 t}=E_{2 t}
\end{array}
\]

The contour is so thin that the area enclosed is practically zero. So, the area integral would be zero for any finite \( B \) field. i.e., the tangential component of \( E \) field is always continuous.

8. Lossy Medium

So far, we have only considered electromagnetic waves propagating in an ideal lossless medium. What happens if a signal travels through a realistic medium, such as a circuit board, or a glass window? How would the signal be affected by the finite conductivity of these materials? This knowledge would, for example, allow us to choose the right circuit board material for the specific frequency range of the signal being transported.
8.1 Ohm's Law

One way to categorize a material is by observing its electrical resistivity. Metal typically has a low resistivity \( \rho \) (in order of \( 10^{-5} \Omega-\mathrm{cm} \) ) which varies linearly with temperature. Because of this temperature linearity property, good conductors are commonly used as thermometers in most ambient conditions. On the other end of the spectrum, good insulators often have resistivity as high as \( 10^{10} \Omega-\mathrm{cm} \) or more. In between, we have semiconductors and other sub-categories that we would not get into here.

Fig. (8.1) - DC voltage applied across a block of material.

The resistivity is an intrinsic property of the material, whereas the resistance of a device includes the geometric factors that impede the current flow. They are related by \( R=\frac{\rho L}{A} \) in a simple geometry as shown in Fig. (8.1). Here, \( L \) is the length of the material where the voltage applied across, and A is the cross-sectional area of the material. Here, Ohm's Law can be written as:
\[
\begin{array}{l}
V=I R \\
E L=(J A)\left(\frac{\rho L}{A}\right) \\
E=\rho J \\
J=\frac{1}{\rho} E \\
\vec{J}=\sigma \vec{E}
\end{array}
\]

Equation (8.1) is the macroscopic Ohm's Law which relates the measurable quantities of voltage and current, whereas Equation (8.2) is its microscopic counterpart. It relates its local current density to the electric field at that location. Equation (8.2) is often referred to the local Ohm's Law. Remember J and E are both vector quantities, so this is also called the Ohm's Law in vector form.

8.2 Loss Tangent

In the last chapter, we applied the Maxwell Equations to the source-free medium in which there is no charge density and current density. Now we are going to allow current in the medium due to the finite conductivity while maintaining no net charge density in the material. This is to mimic the physical scenario when a signal is going through a lossy medium, such as a circuit board, or through the ionosphere.

In terms of E and H fields, the Maxwell Equations read as:
\[
\begin{array}{c}
\varepsilon \nabla \cdot \overrightarrow{\mathrm{E}}=\rho_{\mathrm{f}} \\
\nabla \times \overrightarrow{\mathrm{E}}=-\mu \frac{\partial \overrightarrow{\mathrm{H}}}{\partial \mathrm{t}} \\
\nabla \cdot \overrightarrow{\mathrm{H}}=0 \\
\nabla \times \overrightarrow{\mathrm{H}}=\overrightarrow{\mathrm{J}}_{\mathrm{f}}+\varepsilon \frac{\partial \overrightarrow{\mathrm{E}}}{\partial \mathrm{t}}
\end{array}
\]

With \( \rho_{f}=0 \), and writing them in phasor form, we now have a set of coupled equations:
\[
\begin{array}{c}
\nabla \cdot \overrightarrow{\mathrm{E}}=0 \\
\nabla \times \overrightarrow{\mathrm{E}}=-\mathrm{j} \omega \mu \overrightarrow{\mathrm{H}} \\
\nabla \cdot \overrightarrow{\mathrm{H}}=0 \\
\nabla \times \overrightarrow{\mathrm{H}}=\overrightarrow{\mathrm{J}}_{\mathrm{f}}+\mathrm{j} \omega \varepsilon \overrightarrow{\mathrm{E}}
\end{array}
\]

Applied the local Ohm's Law \( \vec{J}_{f}=\sigma \vec{E} \), the last equation can be written as:
\[
\begin{array}{l}
\nabla \times \overrightarrow{\mathrm{H}}=(\sigma+\mathrm{j} \omega \varepsilon) \overrightarrow{\mathrm{E}}=\mathrm{j} \omega\left(\varepsilon+\frac{\sigma}{\mathrm{j} \omega}\right) \overrightarrow{\mathrm{E}}=\mathrm{j} \omega \varepsilon_{\mathrm{c}} \overrightarrow{\mathrm{E}} \\
\varepsilon_{\mathrm{c}} \equiv \varepsilon-\mathrm{j} \frac{\sigma}{\omega} \equiv \varepsilon^{\prime}-\mathrm{j} \varepsilon^{\prime \prime}
\end{array}
\]

In other words, the curl of H is still proportional to E , if we re-define the permittivity constant as a complex quantity. The real part of this complex permittivity \( \varepsilon_{\mathrm{c}} \) is called \( \varepsilon^{\prime} \), and the imaginary part is \( \varepsilon^{\prime \prime}=\sigma / \omega \). Note that \( \varepsilon \) and \( \varepsilon^{\prime} \) in Eqn. (8.5) are exactly the same quantity. They were just derived from different perspective. The important lesson here is that finite conductivity of the medium can simply be taken care of by allowing the permittivity to be a complex number.

The solution of the wave equation (8.7) can be written in form of:
\[
\vec{E}=\vec{E}_{o} e^{j\left(\omega t-\vec{k}_{c} \cdot \vec{r}\right)}=\vec{E}_{o} e^{j \omega t} e^{-j k_{c} r}
\]

Here, we have assumed k and r are in the same direction (for simplicity). We will discuss how to deal with more complex situations later.

Let us define a complex propagation constant \( \gamma \) :
\[
\gamma \equiv j k_{c}=j \omega \sqrt{\mu \varepsilon_{c}} \equiv \alpha+j \beta
\]

The real part of this propagation constant \( \gamma \) is called the attenuation constant \( \alpha \), and the imaginary part is called the phase constant \( \beta \).

Now the wave equation in Eqn. (8.8) reads as:
\[
\vec{E}=\vec{E}_{o} e^{j \omega t} e^{-\gamma r}=\vec{E}_{o} e^{j \omega t} e^{-\alpha r} e^{-j \beta r}=\vec{E}_{o} e^{-\alpha r} e^{j(\omega t-\beta r)}
\]

Fig. (8.2) - The wave is propagating to the right, and the amplitude is decaying exponentially.

For the most part, Eqn.(8.10) is just a traveling wave propagating in the \( r \) direction except there is an extra factor \( e^{-\alpha r} \). Since \( \alpha \) is a real number, this extra factor defines an exponential decay of the amplitude of the wave. And \( \beta \) is the wave number \( 2 \pi / \lambda \) along the r direction. However, the wavelength is no longer defined by \( \frac{\lambda_{o}}{\sqrt{\varepsilon_{r}}} \) because \( \varepsilon_{\mathrm{r}} \) is not well defined for conductors. It might still be beneficial to associate \( \beta \) with k at this point, so you can visualize it with the wave propagation you have learned. We will discuss their differences in a later paragraph. To recap, if a signal is traveling thru any realistic medium with a finite electrical conductivity, the signal amplitude would decay and thus suffers some power lost.

To evaluate the \( \gamma, \alpha \) and \( \beta \) from the material properties, we go back to the definitions of the complex permittivity in Eqns. (8.5), (8.6) and (8.9).
\[
\gamma=j \omega \sqrt{\mu \varepsilon_{\mathrm{c}}}=j \omega \sqrt{\mu \varepsilon\left(1-\mathrm{j} \frac{\varepsilon^{\prime \prime}}{\varepsilon^{\prime}}\right)}=\mathrm{j} \omega \sqrt{\mu \varepsilon\left(1-\mathrm{j} \frac{\sigma}{\omega \varepsilon}\right)}=j \omega \sqrt{\mu \varepsilon(1-\mathrm{j} \tan \delta)}=\alpha+\mathrm{j} \beta
\]

The propagation constant can be evaluated from any one of these forms, depends on what is given. Of course, they are all equivalent. To further study these parameters, we look at their effect on the electromagnetic waves in various materials.

8.3.2 The low-loss limit \( \left(\varepsilon^{\prime \prime} \ll \varepsilon^{\prime}\right. \), or more specifically, \( \left.\tan \delta=\frac{\varepsilon^{\prime \prime}}{\varepsilon^{\prime}} \leq 0.01\right) \).

If \( \varepsilon^{\prime \prime} \ll \varepsilon^{\prime} \), or equivalently \( \sigma \ll \omega \varepsilon \), then we can rewrite \( \gamma \) as:
\[
\gamma=j \omega \sqrt{\mu \varepsilon\left(1-j \frac{\varepsilon^{\prime \prime}}{\varepsilon^{\prime}}\right)}=j \omega \sqrt{\mu \varepsilon}\left(1-j \frac{\varepsilon^{\prime \prime}}{\varepsilon^{\prime}}\right)^{1 / 2} \approx j \omega \sqrt{\mu \varepsilon}\left(1-j \frac{\varepsilon^{\prime \prime}}{2 \varepsilon^{\prime}}\right)
\]

The last step was derived using the binomial expansion, which stated that:
\[
(1+x)^{n}=1+n x+\frac{n(n-1)}{2!} x^{2}+\cdots \approx 1+n x \text { in the limit of } \mathrm{x} \rightarrow 0
\]

Since \( \gamma=\alpha+\mathrm{j} \beta \), we can just read off \( \alpha \) and \( \beta \) from Eqn. (8.12). i.e.,
\( \beta=\omega \sqrt{\mu \varepsilon} \), and
\[
\alpha=\frac{\omega \sqrt{\mu \varepsilon}}{2} \cdot \frac{\varepsilon^{\prime \prime}}{\varepsilon^{\prime}}=\frac{\omega \sqrt{\mu \varepsilon}}{2} \cdot \frac{\sigma}{\omega \varepsilon}=\frac{\sigma}{2} \sqrt{\frac{\mu}{\varepsilon}} .
\]

The \( \beta \) here is the same as the lossless case, so it is the wave number \( 2 \pi / \lambda \).
\[
\begin{array}{l}
v=\frac{\omega}{\beta}=\frac{\omega}{\omega \sqrt{\mu \varepsilon}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{\mu \varepsilon}} \\
\eta=\sqrt{\frac{\mu}{\varepsilon_{c}}}=\sqrt{\frac{\mu}{\varepsilon^{\prime}-j \varepsilon^{\prime \prime}}}=\sqrt{\frac{\mu}{\varepsilon}}\left(1-j \frac{\varepsilon^{\prime \prime}}{\varepsilon^{\prime}}\right)^{-1 / 2} \approx \sqrt{\frac{\mu}{\varepsilon}}\left(1+j \frac{\varepsilon^{\prime \prime}}{2 \varepsilon^{\prime}}\right) \approx \sqrt{\frac{\mu}{\varepsilon}}
\end{array}
\]

Here, we have used the binomial expansion again, and then take the limit where \( \varepsilon " \rightarrow 0 \). In other words, in the limit of low loss medium, the wave impedance, phase velocity, and wave number are essentially unchanged. It only introduces an attenuation constant \( \alpha \) which is given by \( \alpha=\frac{\sigma}{2} \sqrt{\frac{\mu}{\varepsilon}}=\frac{\sigma}{2} \eta \).

The condition that \( \tan \delta \leq 0.01 \) should be used as a reference only. This is not to say if \( \tan \delta \) \( =0.011 \), then the low loss limit does not apply. Of course, the smaller the loss tangent, the more accurate our calculation would become. This is true for any kind of approximations.

The complex wave impedance has an interesting consequence. Recall that \( \frac{E_{o}}{H_{o}}=\eta \), a complex impedance means there is a phase different between E and H fields. They are no longer in phase! Equation (8.13) also stated that the wavelength is no longer just a simply scale down by the dielectric constant or index of refraction. In fact, these 2 quantities are not easily defined in good conductors and were never used. The phase velocity is also not a simple scaling of \( \frac{c}{n} \). It is instead \( v=\frac{\omega}{\beta}=\sqrt{\frac{2 \omega}{\mu \sigma}} \).

In this good conductor limit, \( \alpha \) is usually a large number, which means the field strength decays rapidly. How far could the electromagnetic field penetrate into a conductor depends on the frequency of the wave among other things. Let us examine the decay factor \( e^{-\alpha r} \) in the wave equation (8.10). When the wave travels a distance \( r=\frac{1}{\alpha} \), the factor becomes \( e^{-1}=0.37 \). This distance is defined as one skin depth. In just one skin depth, the field strength drops \( 63 \% \), and the power (which is proportional to the square of the field strength) drops \( 86 \% \). One skin depth of a good conductor is typically in order of a micron. There are many online skin depth calculators for easy access. For example, the skin depth of copper is about \( 2 \mu \mathrm{~m} \) at 1 GHz , and about \( 0.65 \mu \mathrm{~m} \) at 10 GHz . In 5 skin depths, the field strength drops by \( 99.3 \% \), and its power drops by \( 99.9955 \% \). In other words, if we send a signal between 2 plastic sheets plated with \( 10 \mu \mathrm{~m} \) of copper, the result would be the same as if the signal is going through 2 pieces of copper plates. People do this because plastic is inexpensive and easier to mold for mass production.

Square both sides:

This is a complex equation, so we can extract 2 equations from this. The real part of the left-hand-side is equal to the real part of the right-hand-side. And similarly, the imaginary part of the equations is equated. So, we have:
\[
\begin{array}{l}
-\omega^{2} \mu \varepsilon^{\prime}=\alpha^{2}-\beta^{2} \quad(\text { real }) \\
\omega^{2} \mu \varepsilon^{\prime \prime}=2 \alpha \beta \quad \text { (imaginary) }
\end{array}
\]

Now we have 2 simultaneous equations and 2 variables, we can solve for \( \alpha \) and \( \beta \). Solve for \( \beta \) from the last equation:
\[
\beta=\frac{\omega^{2} \mu \varepsilon^{\prime \prime}}{2 \alpha}

8.4 Attenuation in dB

Attenuation is often expressed in terms of dB scale. For a quick review on dB , please read Appendix F.

Starting with the wave equation (8.10) \( \vec{E}(r)=\vec{E}_{o} e^{-\alpha r} e^{j(\omega t-\beta r)} \), attenuation is simply a measure of how much field strength has decayed at some distance \( r \) later, but in dB scale.
\[

\]

Remember how to convert the \( \log \) base 10 to the natural log? We can use:
\[
\log _{a}(x)=\frac{\log _{b}(x)}{\log _{b}(a)}
\]

So, Eqn. (8.21) now reads as:
\[
A(r)=-20 \frac{\ln \left(e^{-\alpha r}\right)}{\ln (10)}=8.686 \alpha r
\]

The numeric factor 8.686 came from \( 20 / \ln (10) \), which shows up every time one converts a number to dB scale. It is a number perhaps worth remembering. We will show that in the next example.

The negative sign in the definition of Eqn. (8.21) is sometimes omitted in other literature but understood that attenuation means lower power. So, when people say, "the system lost -2 dB of power" for example, you can bet they really mean "the system lost 2 dB of power", or the power is 2 dB lower. Note that in here we said power lost. Regardless of what is given, when we calculate it in dB , we are already talking about power lost.

Example (8.4) - If the electric field intensity going through a cable attenuates at a rate of \( 0.4 \mathrm{~dB} / \mathrm{m} \). What is the attenuation constant \( \alpha \) ?

In one meter, \( 0.4 d B=8.686 \alpha, \alpha=\frac{0.4}{8.686}=0.046 \mathrm{~Np} / \mathrm{m} \).
Note: Nepers ( Np ) is not a real unit. It is just a pure number, and Np is there to remind us we are talking about power. Similarly, Radians (rad) is not a real unit. It is just a pure number, and radian is there to remind us we are dealing with an angle.

The answer \( \alpha \) must be a positive real number, otherwise \( e^{-\alpha r} \) would not represent an attenuation.

Also note that if the question is changed to "If the power of a signal going through a cable attenuates at a rate of.....", the answer would still be the same. Again, this is because the dB scale already taken the power into account. So, the \( 0.4 \mathrm{~dB} / \mathrm{m} \) is always the attenuation of the power amplitude, and not the field strength.
8.5 Differences between k and \( \beta \)

This is often a confusion between k and \( \beta \) because they are interchangeable in most literatures and for most cases. Although they contain more or less the same meaning, there are some subtle differences.

In wave propagation, \( \beta \) is often used when the propagation direction is along a unique direction, say along the z-axis, for example as in \( \vec{E}=\vec{E}_{o} \cos (\omega t-\beta z) \). Whereas k is often used in terms of a 3-dimensional propagation vector such as \( \vec{E}=\vec{E}_{o} \cos (\omega t-\vec{k} \cdot \vec{r}) \), where \( \vec{k} \) may take a form, for example: \( \vec{k}=2 \hat{x}-3 \hat{z} \).

Very often, the z-direction is taken as the direction of the transmission line (along a coaxial cable, or a trace on a circuit board), then using the function \( \cos (\omega t-\beta z) \) is convenient. However, in some scenario, such as in the first exercise of the Maxwell Equations chapter, \( \beta \) is only the \( z \)-component of the wave vector \( k \). For example, in a waveguide, we would use this to describe the electromagnetic wave: \( \vec{E}=\hat{y} E_{o} \sin \left(\frac{\pi}{a} x\right) \cos (\omega t-\beta z) \). i.e.,
\[
\vec{k}=k_{x} \hat{x}+k_{y} \hat{y}+k_{z} \hat{z}=k_{x} \hat{x}+k_{y} \hat{y}+\beta \hat{z}
\]

And in this example, \( k_{x}=\frac{\pi}{a} \).

In this chapter, when we defined the propagation constant \( \gamma=\alpha+j \beta \), we were assuming the propagation is in one-dimensional, and so \( \gamma \) is just scalar complex number. But in general, \( \gamma \) is a vector, and the generalization is the same as from \( \beta \) to \( \vec{k} \). So how do we deal with the vector \( \gamma \) ? Or more specifically, how do we write \( e^{-\alpha r} \) ?
8.6 Attenuation factor \( e^{-\alpha r} \) in 3-dimensions

Consider a signal is traveling along the r direction as shown in figure. If the attenuation constant is \( \alpha \), then after some distance \( r \) later, the wave amplitude would be reduced by \( e^{-\alpha r}=e^{-\alpha \sqrt{x^{2}+y^{2}}} \).

Alternatively, if we consider \( \alpha \) is a vector, which has a direction of k , such that: \( \vec{\alpha}=\alpha \hat{k}=\alpha(\hat{x} \cos \theta+\hat{y} \sin \theta) \), the attenuation factor now reads \( e^{-\vec{\alpha} \cdot \vec{r}}=e^{-\alpha(x \cos \theta+y \sin \theta)} \).

Note that: \( x \cos \theta+y \sin \theta=x\left(\frac{x}{r}\right)+y\left(\frac{y}{r}\right)=\frac{x^{2}+y^{2}}{r}=\frac{r^{2}}{r}=r=\sqrt{x^{2}+y^{2}} \). So clearly, either way would give the correct answer. The latter technique seems to be more nature as an extension of how we write the wave equation.
